title: Can I write horror if I don't even get scared? - Quora

response.answer_text: Yes. Many people think horror is about scaring the audience, but it’s not. Horror is about evoking a primal emotional discomfort. Fear is one way to do that, but it isn’t the only way. Horror is about finding what makes your audience anxious, what speaks to their sense of foreboding or unease, and then expressing that—often through allegory or analogy. It’s about creating a mood. It’s about evocation. Fear is an easy way to do that (and sometimes a cheap way; jump-scares in movies make me roll my eyes). But it doesn’t necessarily have to be about scaring you, even though there’s often a feeling of dread that accompanies horror. Kafka’s The Trial is horror, but it uses confusion and powerlessness, not fear. The Handmaid’s Tale is horror that plays on themes of despair. You can paint horror with a palette of claustrophobia, angst, disillusionment, desperation, uncertainty, or dread. However you do it, horror is personal. Effective horror doesn’t necessarily have to frighten your audience, but it does need to make them feel personally invested. It needs to evoke a genuine reaction. You can do that by pushing buttons we all have. Body horror pushes the button of bodily integrity, wired into our collective psyche since the days when we were prey almost as often as we were predators. The Thing and Invasion of the Body Snatchers push on fear of dissolution of the self. Alien wasn’t just a monster movie; it specifically targeted sexual angst. (It’s one thing to be eaten by a monster; it’s another to be impregnated by one!) You can write horror if you don’t get scared, but you’re unlikely to write effective horror if you don’t feel anything. You need to find some disquiet that you can project onto your audience.

I don’t get scared of my own work, even though I’ve been told some parts are dark and suspenseful. So, yes, you don’t have to get scared to write horror. In fact, it’s probably best that you don’t. That way, you can analyze horror literature and learn how to write good horror stories. Much of horror is a morality play. In other words, people often get killed gruesomely because of something they’ve done. Other horror — Silence of the Lambs, comes to mind, which is more of a suspense—deals with the deaths of innocents and how the hero will overcome the ghastly evil. In Jaws, the skinny dipper, a child who ignored the warnings and went out too far, and Quint get killed because of their behavior. Martin Brody survives because he is the “white knight” who must slay the “dragon” (the great white), along with Hooper, who provides the critical information about sharks. Some horror stories have a sense of despair associated with them. The protagonist has son great sin he or she eventually atones for. The original movie, The Poseidon Adventure, is actually a horror because almost everyone dies, and even the hero must atone for challenging god. Edgar Allen Poe wrote many horrors where the protagonist has a deadly secret. So, I know this is long-winded, but you see what I’m getting at. Writing horror is like writing any other genre. Read a lot of good horror and analyze why it is good. Watch decent horror movies (not necessarily slasher films, unless you really want to write that) and analyze why the story works. Good luck!

Uhm, I’d like to think so.. The truth is, writing mostly comes from your ability to imagine. This includes scenarios, characters and so on. And although being scared helps, it’s not really a factor that would or should stop you from writing in the horror genre. However, most people who write the best horror flicks or even the best horror movies had some level of reality to it. This means that, the writer (the original writer at least) had his horror characters come from a real world experience. It could have been a dream, a metaphor for a real life bad experience or something else entirely. But it’s also important to note that, original ideas about writing horror stories can also come from you and your ability to imagine the scariest of situations. So to answer your question, I’d say it’s very possible. But try to make sure your idea for the writing comes from an original place as that helps in developing your characters in the long run..😇

Horror isn’t scaring yourself. Horror is depicting something that causes a visceral response in the reader. To that end, using tight narrative and pacing to create tension. Using physical registers and attention to senses to make a story immersive. Dark themes that invoke the imagination. Some of the best horror is not bloody or violent. Consider Harlan Ellison’s story title: A Have no Mouth and I Must Scream. Provocative, right?

Yes, absolutely. In fact, it’s probably better if you don’t get scared. It means that you won’t back out of a scary concept. I admit I’m a wimp about horror. That means that I may cop out on something genuinely scary. When you aren’t scared, it means you are willing to go further and optimize the fear. Take risks, and take the leap.

Yeah, I’m sure you can. I have horror stories of my own and I don’t get scared that easily. It doesn’t have to rely on your current mood. Writing horror can be fun to work on say like for a ghost story or other topics like werewolves, vampires, and so forth.

My first book of all was not intended for horror but it was regarded as horror even tough its not. You can use some dark places and suspense, in the end, if you are any good you can scare a little bit. It requires a lot of skill, horror these days is not like before. You need to enter people’s mind and try to be part of their dark occult think side.
